Title: > Domestic workers – The law, rights and Responsibilities
Content:
Matilda is a career woman working in a professional office in Westlands, Nairobi. For the last five years she had employed Rose as a house keeper, whose duty was among others house chores, taking care of the children and cooking. Rose’s day starts at 05.00 a.m. with washing cars and making breakfast for Baba Kazee before he leaves for work at 06.30 a.m. Thereafter, she prepares the children to go to school and thereafter attends to house chores. When children get back from school at 4 p.m., she washes them, makes them an afternoon snack, cooks dinner and serves them by 7.00 p.m. She thereafter cleans up and eventually retires to sleep at about 09.00 p.m.

Rose earns a monthly salary of Kshs. 10,000. She lives in the homestead and eats what she cooks for the rest of the family. Rose goes to church early on Sunday mornings and doesn’t come back until late in the afternoon. Whenever Rose is unwell Matilda ensured that she foots the bills. Rose is not under any medical scheme including NHIF. She agreed with Matilda that she does not want to pay NSSF or any other deductions from her salary. The terms of employment are all verbal and it has worked out well for both of them.

Rose has been a fantastic employee until the last three months when Matilda noticed that Rose’s attitude had drastically changed. She got very moody, insolent and harsh to the children. She had also become lazy. She slept till late in the morning and on a few occasions, Baba Kazee went to work without breakfast and the house stayed unkept. Matilda had on several occasions politely discussed Rose’s change in behaviour with her without any improvement. She was very relieved that Rose agreed to leave employment without any drama. Matilda paid Rose her salary and she left.

Last week, Matilda received a letter from Kenya Union of Domestic Hotels Educational Institutions Hospitals & Allied Workers (KUDHEIHA). Rose’s claims among others were:

  1. She was not given or paid for notice before termination.
  2. Salary underpayment.
  3. She had not taken leave for the last five years.
  4. She was not paid overtime. She was working from 5.00 a.m. to 9.00 p.m.
  5. Service pay for 5 years.
  6. Damages for unfair termination.
  7. Unremitted NSSF and NHIF dues.

        Who is a domestic worker?

        According to Order 2 of Regulation of Wages (Domestic Servants Wages Council Establishment) Order, a domestic servant refers to any person employed wholly in any private household in any of the following capacities, namely cook, house servant (including bedroom and kitchen servant), waiter, butler, children’s nurse, chauffeur, bar attendant, groom, gardener, or watchman. Rose was therefore a domestic worker in Matilda’s household.

        Rights of an employee

        According to Section 2 of both the Employment Act and Labour Relations Act, an employee is a person employed for wages or a salary and includes an apprentice and indentured learner. Domestic workers are also employees within the meaning of the law.

        According to, Article 41 (2) of the Constitution of Kenya (CoK) an employee is entitled to:

        1. Fair remuneration;
        2. To reasonable working conditions; and
        3. To form, join or participate in the activities and programs of a trade union.

          The Employment Act and other laws, expound on the above constitutional preserves for an employee as follows:

               i) Basic minimum conditions of employment

          Under Section 26 of the Employment Act, an employee is entitled to basic minimum terms and conditions of employment including fair remuneration, humane working conditions and basic terms regulated by any collective bargaining agreement.

          The Regulation of Wages (General) (Amendment) Order of 2018, provides for the minimum remuneration of domestic workers based on location. Domestic workers in the cities of Nairobi, Kisumu and Mombasa ought to be paid a minimum of Kshs. 13,572.90 per month. Those in former municipalities or town councils of Mavoko, Ruiru and Limuru ought to be paid a minimum of Kshs. 12, 522.70, while those in all other areas ought to be paid a minimum of Kshs. 7,240.95 per month excluding house allowance. (Valid as at September 2020)

          Employers, be aware that any agreement to pay a domestic worker below the minimum prescribed wage is not protected by the law. The Courts have been categorical that the minimum wage must be adhered to. In the case of Robai Musinzi v Sadfar Mohamed Khan (2012), the Court ruled that domestic workers are entitled to the minimum wage provided in the Regulation of Wages Order.

               ii) Right to leave

          Under Section 27 to 30 of the Employment Act, Employees are entitled to:

          1. One rest day in every seven day period of service;
          2. At least twenty-one working days of annual leave with full pay;
          3. Three months maternity leave or two weeks paternity leave with full pay; and
          4. Sick leave of not less than seven days on full pay and seven days on half pay.
               iii) Working hours

          The prescribed maximum working hours for an employee is fifty-two hours every week. Working hours in excess of the fifty-two hours is considered overtime. Order 6 of the Regulations of Wages (General) Order, overtime is payable in addition to the salary at the rate of 1/225th of the monthly salary per hour.

          Working time evaluation for domestic workers is difficult given the nature of their work. Their working hours depend on the Employers schedule. There is also no clear measure of the actual time they work and the intermittent breaks they take.

          Section 27 of the Employment Act, gives leeway to the Employer to regulate the working hours in accordance with the law. This means that parties can agree how working hours are managed and whether there is payment of overtime for as long it is within the law. For example, the Employer and the Employee can agree on a salary that is all inclusive of overtime or other contributions (for as long as the salary is above the prescribed minimum).

          In absence of an employment agreement the onus of proof of any term of employment is on the Employer as the law requires that the Employer must give an employment agreement to any person in employment for more than three months.

               iv) Medical attention

          Under Section 34 of the Employment Act, the Employer is required to provide sufficient medication to an employee during illness. Medication is unpredictable and sometimes can be very expensive. This requirement is satisfied if the Employee is under NHIF cover or other medical insurance scheme.

               v) Right to housing

          Section 31 of the Employment Act, requires that an Employer should provide reasonable housing or alternatively pay house allowance. Section 31 (2), provides that housing allowance shall not apply if the contract of service provides for a consolidated pay that is inclusive of house allowance.

          Where housing is not provided or where there is no employment contract, the Courts interpretation has been that the salary provided is basic salary and house allowance at the rate of 15% of basic pay should be paid in addition. In the case Caroline Wanjiru Luzze v Nestle Equatorial African Region Limited, (2016), the Court ruled that housing allowance should be added to the basic pay if it is not part of a consolidated salary or not being provided by the employer.

               vi) Provision of water and food

          An employer is required to provide water to the employees at the place of employment. Provision of drinking water suffices unless the Employer is providing accommodation in which case the Employer shall provide water within a reasonable distance of the accommodation.

          Provision of food is not a mandatory requirement unless it is an agreed term of contract.

               vii) Termination notice

          Section 35 of the Employment Act, provides that an Employee on a monthly salary should be given termination notice of at least 28 days. Alternatively, the Employer is required to pay salary in lieu of notice. Similarly, when the Employee is resigning they are required to give equivalent notice.

               viii)  NSSF contributions.

          Section 20 of National Social Security Fund (NSSF) Act, provides that the Employer is required to pay the prescribed amount and contribute an equivalent amount to the Fund. It is the Employers obligation to remit both the Employers and Employees contributions to the fund.

          Responsibilities of an Employee

          1. To obey the terms and conditions under the employment contract;
          2. Not to absent from duty without reasonable cause;
          3. To perform their duties diligently and responsibly;
          4. Not to use any intoxicants or drugs during working hours;
          5. Not to use abusive language on the employer or a person in authority;
          6. To obey lawful instruction by the employer; and
          7. Not to commit any offences against the employer.

                A review of the case scenario

                1. Was Matilda obliged to respond to the claim by the KUDHEIHA? - The Employer is obliged to respond and report to the Labour officer if summoned.
                2. Was Rose entitled to termination notice or payment in lieu? - Yes. Unless Rose resigned on her own volition (in writing).
                3. Was Matilda underpaying Rose? – Yes. The minimum prescribed for Nairobi is Kshs. 13,572.90. Rose is entitled to the underpayment for each year as prescribed in the Regulation of Wages (General) (Amendment) Order for each year.
                4. How many days leave is Rose entitled to? – 21 days for every completed year of service and pro rata 1.75 days for every month.
                5. Is Rose entitled to overtime? – Yes for 7hrs and 20 minutes every day. She was required to work for only 8.6 hours every day.
                6. Is Rose entitled to service pay? – Yes as per Section 35(6) of the Employment Act, at the rate of 15 days for each completed year of service (unless she was on NSSF or any other pension scheme).
                7. Is Rose entitled to the unremitted NSSF and NHIF dues? – No. However, nothing prohibits NSSF and NHIF to claim the remittances being a statutory obligation of the Employer.
                8. Rose and Matilda agreed that Roses salary should not have NSSF and NHIF or other deductions. Was this valid agreement? – No. Parties are prohibited to contract for an illegal purpose. NSSF and NHIF can at any time call for the deductions from Matilda.
                9. Is Rose entitled to damages for unfair termination? – Only if Rose can prove that there was an invalid reason for termination or that the procedure for termination was not followed.

                Conclusion

                Domestic workers are a special category of employees and many of them are semi- literate. Kenyan jurisprudence through the Employment and Labour Relations Court has adopted a very lenient approach to the employee given their educational exposure and greater responsibility is placed upon the Employers. The burden of proof of the terms of engagement rests with the Employer and the courts approach has been unless under written contract, the court will not make an unfavourable interpretation of any term of contract against the Employee. The Court in the case of Stella Mukoko Amutabi v Saijal Shikotra (2014), ruled that an Employer has the duty to inform the employee whenever there is a change in the terms of the contract preferably in writing, and in a language the Employee understands.

                To avoid unnecessary and complicated disputes with your domestic workers it is easier and safer to draw up an employment agreement with clear terms and conditions of engagement.

                SOURCES

                1. Constitution of Kenya, 2010
                2. Employment Act, No. 11 of 2007
                3. Labour Relations Act, 14 of 2007
                4. National Social Security Fund (NSSF) Act, 2013
                5. Regulation of Wages (General) Order
                6. Regulation of Wages (General) (Amendment) Order, 2018
                7. Regulation of Wages (Domestic Servants Wages Council Establishment) Order, 2018
                8. Robai Musinzi v Sadfar Mohamed Khan, 2012 eKLR
                9. Caroline Wanjiru Luzze v Nestle Equatorial African Region Limited, 2016 eKLR
                10. Stella Mukoko Amutabi v Saijal Shikotra, 2014 eKLR

Title: > Are you an Employee or an Independent Contractor
Content:
You have a gardener who tends to your garden from Monday to Saturday. You pay them a monthly salary. However, your gardener is only in your house from 6 a.m. to 9.00 a.m., and then he leaves for work elsewhere. Is he your Employee, or is he an independent contractor.

There has been an increase in the flexibility of employment relationships, with many adopting independent contractor agreements as opposed to Employees. The law distinguishes Employees from independent contractors. An Employer-Employee relationship creates an employment contract known as a contract of service while a client contractor relationship creates an independent contractor agreement known as a contract for services. What distinguishes the two contracts?

What is a Contract of Service

Section 2 of the Employment Act defines a contract of service as an agreement, whether oral or in writing, to employ or to serve as an Employee for a period of time. It includes internships. Therefore, a contract of service is an agreement between an Employer and an Employee containing the terms of engagement.

Section 9 of the Act provides that a contract for service for three months or more must be in writing. This contract must state particulars of employment and must be given within two months of employment.

The case of Ready Mixed Concrete (South East) Ltd v Minister of Pensions and National Insurance (1968) set out the conditions required to establish a contract of service. It stated that a contract of service will be established where:

(i)           The servant agrees to provide his own work and skill by providing a service for their master, in consideration of a wage or other remuneration.

(ii)          The servant agrees that in the performance of that service they will be subject to the master’s control. Control includes the power of deciding the thing to be done, the way in which it shall be done, the means to be employed in doing it, the time, and the place where it shall be done.

(iii)         The contract of service complies with the terms of an employment agreement. This entails complying with the statutory requirements in the Employment Act including minimum wage, provision for leave and payment of income tax.

What does a contract of service entail?

i.        the Employees details;

ii.        the Employers details;

iii.        the job description;

iv.        commencement date of the employment;

v.        the duration of the contract;

vi.        the place of work;

vii.        the hours of work;

viii.        the remuneration and details of any other benefits;

ix.        the intervals at which remuneration is paid; and

x.        any other prescribed matter.

Who is an Employer?

An Employer is defined in the Act as any person, or body who has entered into a contract of service to employ any individual or company. According to the Black’s Law dictionary, an Employer is one who controls a worker under a contract and pays the worker a salary or a wage. A salary is defined as an agreed compensation for services paid at regular intervals, normally monthly. A wage on the other hand is payment for labour or services usually based on time worked or quantity produced. It includes every form of remuneration for personal services.

The Income Tax Act defines an Employer as any resident person responsible for the payment of, or on account of, emoluments to an Employee.

Therefore, an Employer is one who enters into a contract with an individual or company, is in control of the worker, pays them a salary and then remits their taxes to the Kenya Revenue Authority.

Who is an Employee?

Section 2 of the Act defines an Employee as a person employed for wages or a salary and includes an intern. According to the Black’s law dictionary, an Employee is one who works in the service of another person, under the Employer’s control.

Rights of an Employee

Rule 7 of the Employment General Rules states that an Employer shall issue a statement stipulating the rights of an Employee. This statement shall be placed in a conspicuous place, which is accessible to all Employees. The statement should include the following rights. The right:

i.        To be issued with a letter of appointment for an Employee engaged on a continuous service for more than three months. The letter of employment should include the employment details;

ii.        To one rest day in every period of seven days;

iii.        To at least twenty-one working days leave during a period of twelve months continuous service;

iv.        To three months maternity leave with full pay for female Employees;

v.        To sick leave of at least seven days with full pay and seven days at half pay;

vi.        To housing allowance or provision of a house or a wage which is inclusive of house allowance;

vii.        To compensation by the Government in the event of insolvency of the Employer;

viii.        To be paid wages at intervals agreed, subject to deductions authorized by law;

ix.        To work for a maximum of fifty-two hours of work spread over six days of the week ,sixty hours of work per week for a person employed on night work, and less than six hours a day for a person under the age of sixteen years;

x.        To be paid wages at the end of each day where the Employee is a casual Employee;

xi.        To be issued with an itemized pay statement where an Employee is on a continuous contract for more than six months;

xii.        To termination notice of 28 days, however, where the contract is for payment of daily wages, either party may terminate at the close of any day without notice;

xiii.        To at least fifteen days pay for each completed year of service where the Employee is terminated on account of redundancy;

xiv.        To a disciplinary hearing for misconduct where the Employee has had a continuous contract with an Employer for more than thirteen months; and

xv.        To a certificate of service upon termination of the contract.

https://www.lawyerwangu.com/employment/employment-agreements/certificate-of-service/

Case analysis

i)     The case of Everret Aviation Limited vs the Kenya Revenue Authority (2013) determined whether a contract of service or a contract for services existed. The facts of the case are that Everret sub-contracted pilots to undertake special tasks. They had two sets of pilots, that is resident freelance pilots and non-resident freelance pilots who both did the same work. KRA audited the Companies accounts as it considered the payments made to the pilots as salaries that were subject to PAYE. KRA held that PAYE was payable for the resident pilots while withholding tax was payable for the non-resident pilots and demanded Kshs. 6,699,425 being PAYE for the years 2000-2002. Everret contested KRA’s finding stating that the pilots were not Employees as:

a.            the pilots were not integrated into the appellants business;

b.            the pilots procured their pilot licences independently;

c.            they were employed for a few hours or weeks;

d.            they were not paid a monthly wage; and

e.            the Employer had no control over the pilots.

The High Court held that Everret was in control of the pilots as it bore the risk of profit, paid the pilots, released them, and identified their tasks. The court argued that the pilots were being paid directly and not to a 3rd party and therefore, it was a contract of services, making the Employer Liable to pay PAYE for both the resident and non-resident pilots. It held that when distinguishing a contract of service from a contract for services, the traditional tests of control of the work by the Employer and its integration into the Employer's core business are no longer conclusive. The fundamental behaviour of the parties such as the form of documentation evidencing the relationship and the mode of payment is critical.

In my opinion, this conclusion is contradictory as the court based its judgement on the level of control the Employer exercised over the pilot, and then went on to say that the level of control is no longer a conclusive measure. They also stated that the courts should look at the mode of payment where monthly salaries and wages are paid to Employees and not independent Contractors. The pilots were not paid a monthly salary and the courts still went ahead and concluded that the pilots were Employees and not independent Contractors.

ii)    In the case of Paul Ochieng’ Agola v Gateway Marine Services Limited [2018] EKLR, the Claimant averred that he was an Employee of the respondent as a Machine Operator, in the year 2012 where he earned a monthly salary of Kshs. 24,000.  The Respondent summarily dismissed him, on 19th March 2016.  He sued the Employer, stating that his dismissal was unfair. The terms of employment were that he was employed as a Casual Employee, who was engaged on and off, depending on availability of work, between 2012 to 2015 and was paid a daily wage. The Respondent however held he was an independent contractor. The Claimant adduced evidence including a copy of leave application supporting the view that he enjoyed an employment benefit of paid annual leave.

The Court held that there was no independent contract between the Parties, as there was no oral or documentary proof of such a contract. It held that the Claimant was a casual worker, who was paid a monthly wage and enjoyed the benefits of an Employee, and therefore, he was unfairly dismissed. The court stated that Independent Contractors do not enjoy employment benefits like annual leave and neither are they paid wages.

In this case, the court looked at the terms of engagement of the parties such as the mode of payment and the employment benefits to determine whether the Claimant was an Employee. A contractor would not enjoy leave days and therefore it was rational to conclude that the Claimant was indeed an Employee and not an independent Contractor as insinuated by the Employer.

What is a Contract for Services

This is an agreement between two parties, where one party provides a service to the other in consideration for payment. This agreement appoints a self-employed person (Independent contractor) such as a consultant to carry out services for another party.

Who is an independent contractor?

The Black’s Law dictionary defines an Independent Contractor as one who is entrusted to undertake a specific project, but who is left free to do the assigned work and choose the method for accomplishing it. The independent contractor is liable for their actions unlike an Employee where the Employer is vicariously liable for their actions.

An Independent Contractor performs work for another Person, according to the Independent Contractor’s own processes and methods. They carry out business on their own account. They are not under the control of the client. They are bound by the terms of the contract and do not get statutory benefits unlike Employees. A contract for services agreement does not create an Employer-Employee relationship.

Case analysis

i)     In the case of Fredrick Byakika v Mutiso Menezes International Unlimited (2016), the Claimant sought payment for unfair dismissal. The facts of the case are that he was employed as a resident engineer for a project in Kampala for a period of 12 months. The terms of the contract were that the claimant would be paid a monthly gross remuneration of $5,260.00 upon issuance of an invoice and subject to withholding tax at 5%. One month into the contract, he fell ill and could not perform his duties. The respondent then terminated the contract. The Claimant was paid Kshs. 240,000.00 as terminal dues. The Claimant then sued the Employer, stating that the summary dismissal was wrongful. The Claimant argued that he was the Respondents Employee as he was the project representative meaning he was under the control of the respondent. He also stated that he had a schedule where he was required to follow and therefore argued that he was integrated within the work of the respondent. The court however held that the Claimant was appointed as a Consultant and was required to be part of the Project Consultancy Team as a Resident Engineer for the project. He was therefore not entitled to the Employee benefits he was seeking.

The Court described an Independent Contractor as a registered taxpayer who will work their own hours, run their own business, is free to carry out work for more than one Employer at the same time, invoices the Employer each month, and is not subject to employment terms such as deduction of PAYE, annual leave, and sick leave. It also held that the use of the terms such as salary, employment terms and conditions, summary dismissal do not, by themselves, confer an employment relationship. The Courts would have to look into factors such as the intention of the parties, to determine whether they give rise to an employment contract or that of an independent contractor.

Therefore, even though the Claimant was paid a monthly salary, the salary was subject to withholding tax and not PAYE. Where the payment is subject to withholding tax, it means that there is no Employer-Employee relationship but an independent contractor relationship. In an Employer-Employee relationship, the Employer will pay the Employee’s tax as PAYE to KRA.

ii)    In Maurice Oduor Okech v. The Chequered Flag Limited [2011] EKLR, the court held that the Claimant was an independent contractor and not an Employee. The facts of the case are that the Claimant was by oral agreement, employed by the Respondent as a cushion maker on 7th August 1998. He was paid between Kshs. 25,000-30,000 at the end of each completed assignment. His contract was terminated in October 2010. He brought a claim seeking remedies for unfair termination.

The respondent held that the Claimant was an independent Contractor, and not an Employee, and therefore unable to claim remedies as an Employee. The Claimant stated that he was an Employee as he was integrated into the business as he was working in the respondent’s office. He then produced an employment card and a photo in the company uniform to prove that he was an Employee. According to the respondent, he issued the Claimant with an Employee card, which did not have an Employee number, in order to avoid harassment by the Police while going home at night. He also claimed that he had allowed the Claimant to work from his office for some time but later asked him to leave after he brought unauthorised people to the office on various occasions. On 13th of October 2013, the Respondent sent the Claimant Kshs. 11,500 to buy material for a customer but failed to deliver. The respondent then terminated the contract.

The court held that the documentation produced i.e. the local purchase orders and the payment vouchers were documents used in contracts for services. It also held that the mode of payment i.e. payment after completion of a job and issuing of an invoice to the respondent to pay, are modes of payment used in contracts for services. Therefore, the Claimant was not an Employee of the Respondent but an independent contractor under a contract for services.

Therefore, an independent contractor could be integrated into the Employers business, including adhering to the dress code, reporting time and having an employment card, but still be an independent contractor. In this case, it was clear that the Claimant was contracted for a specific service and was paid after issuing an invoice after delivery of the service. The courts will therefore look beyond the traditional test of integration into the Employers business, and will look into the engagement of the parties in order to determine whether it is a contract of service or for services.

Conclusion

The Employment Act will bind an Employer-Employee relationship. However, it does not bind an independent contractor agreement.

Employers are very quick to state that the Employee is an independent Contractor and not an Employee when an issue arises, in order to escape from the responsibilities required in an Employer-Employee relationship. It is prudent for Employers to have contracts with their Employees in order to avoid blurring the line and having an ambiguous contract that does not have clear terms. The illustration given above of the gardener could create either contract. Where the terms of engagement are not clear, the gardener could be considered a part time domestic worker who has the rights of an Employee. However, if the Employer draws up a contract and stipulates that the gardener be contracted as an independent Contractor for the provision of gardening services, then the gardener will be an independent Contractor. It is advisable for Employers and Employees, and Clients and independent Contractors to reduce their relationship in writing to avoid ambiguity.

Sources

1.    Employment Act (Act No. 11 of 2007).

2.    Ready Mixed Concrete (South East) Ltd v Minister of Pensions and National Insurance (1968) 2 QB 497.

3.    Section 2 Income Tax Act.

4.    The Black’s Law Dictionary eighth edition.

5.    The Employment General Rules 2014.

6.    Paul Ochieng’ Agola v Gateway Marine Services Limited (2018) EKLR.

7.    Everret Aviation Limited vs the Kenya Revenue Authority (2013) EKLR Income Tax Appeal 2 of 2009.

8.    Fredrick Byakika v Mutiso Menezes International Unlimited (2016) EKLR Cause 327 of 2014.

9.    Maurice Oduor Okech v. The Chequered Flag Limited (2011) EKLR.

Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This arbitration agreement is signed by the parties to allow for a dispute arising from a transaction to be resolved through arbitration. REQUIREMENTS • Name and address of the parties. • Description of the dispute referred to arbitration. • Specification of the arbitrator(s) appointed. • Specification of how costs of the arbitration shall be borne and secured by the parties. PROCESS • Fill in this agreement • Each party to sign before a witness. • Present the agreement for stamp duty at the nearest lands registry within 30 days • The Claimant to prepare and serve a statement of claim to all the parties.

Title: > Application for Lost or Damaged Title (Individual)
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This is an application for replacement of a lost or damaged Land Title or Lease. It comprises of an application in form LRA 12, a statutory declaration and a Deed of Indemnity. REQUIREMENTS • Title Number. • Name, ID, PIN and address of Applicant (land owner or personal representative). PROCEDURE • Fill in this application form and sign before an Advocate. • Stamp and register the Deed of Indemnity at the appropriate Land Registry within 30 days. • Submit the application together with an official search and Police abstract to the Land Registry. • The Registrar shall issue a Gazette Notice (for 60 days) • Check for the new Title from the Land Registry after 60 days of gazettement.

Title: > Application for Lost or Damaged Title(Corporate)
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This application is for replacement of a lost or damaged Land Title by a corporate. It comprises of an Application Form (form LRA 12), Affidavit, Deed of Indemnity and a Resolution. REQUIREMENTS • Title Number. • Name, ID, PIN and address of Authorized Signatory of the proprietor (e.g Director, Attorney, Partner, Trustee e.t.c). PROCEDURE • Fill in this application form. • Sign and swear the affidavit before an Advocate. • Stamp and register the Deed of Indemnity within 30 days (at the Land Registry where the title is registered). • Submit the Application for replacement of title together with an official search, company or institution search, registered deed of indemnity, copy of map or mutation, Police abstract e.t.c to the Land Registry. • The Registrar will issue a Gazette Notice (for 60 days). • Check for the new Title from the Land Registry after 60 days of gazettement date.

Title: > Application for Forced Transfer of a Motor Vehicle Where Seller is Absent
Content: This application and affidavits are required by NTSA to transfer a motor vehicle to a purchaser where the registered owner is absent or cannot be traced. REQUIREMENTS • Name of the registered owner. • Motor vehicle registration number. • Original logbook. • Tape lift report. • Supporting documents of how the motor vehicle was acquired by the applicant. • Copy of the registered owners ID and Tax PIN. PROCESS • Fill in this application • Swear the affidavit before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Submit application on your NTSA TIMS account. NB: The Affidavit declaring the Registered Owner missing MUST be sworn before a Magistrate.

Title: > Application for Forced Transfer of a Motor Vehicle by Personal Representative
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This application letter an affidavit are required by NTSA to transfer a motor vehicle of a deceased person to a beneficiary in the estate or a person who had bought from the deceased. The application is made by a Personal Representative i.e Administrator or Executor. REQUIREMENTS: • Name of the Deceased and copy of death certificate. • Name of the beneficial owner. • Motor vehicle registration number. • Original logbook. • Tape lift report. • Grant of Representation. • Certified copy of Confirmation of Grant or Agreement between the deceased and the beneficiary transferring the motor vehicle. PROCESS: • Fill in this application. • Sign the affidavit before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Present the affidavit the application to an NTSA office near you.

Title: > Agent's Mandate Letter to sell
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This is an letter of mandate to an Agent, to sell on your behalf e.g for real estate; motor vehicle; business. This letter is issued by the property owner. REQUIREMENTS • Name and address of Agent • Property details. • Commission amount. PROCESS • Fill in and sign this letter. • Property owner to keep one copy and Agent to keep the other.

Title: > Commission Letter to find Tenant
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This Commission letter is required by an Agent to engaged to find a tenant. The letter is signed by the Landlord and accepted and Agent. REQUIREMENTS • Name and address of Agent • Description of the Property • Commission amount • Rent amount, rent deposit, service charge and who will pay for utilities. PROCESS • Fill in this letter and sign. • Tenant to accept the letter before a witness. Landlord and Agent each to retain a copy.

Title: > Affidavit of Resignation by a Partner
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This Affidavit and letter are required to be filed with Registrar of Companies upon resignation by a Partner. REQUIREMENTS • Name of Partnership • Date of resignation PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Upload the affidavit, the letter in support of application for resignation of a Partner on the Business Registration Services portal on e-citizen.

Title: > Affidavit of Resignation by a Director of a Company
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This Affidavit and letter are required to be filed with Registrar of Companies within 14 days of resignation of resignation of Director. REQUIREMENTS • Name of Company. • Date of resignation. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Upload the affidavit, the letter and minutes of resignation in support of application for resignation on the Business Registration Services portal on e-citizen.

Title: > Affidavit & Letter of Resignation by a Director
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This Affidavit and letter are required to be filed with Registrar of Companies within 14 days of resignation of resignation of Director. REQUIREMENTS • Name of Company. • Date of resignation PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Upload the affidavit, the letter and minutes of resignation in support of application for resignation on the Business Registration Services portal on e-citizen.

Title: > Affidavit of no Impediment to Marriage
Content:
This is an affidavit by a person intending to get married, confirming that they are free to marry i.e. single, divorced or widowed. It is required under section 32 of the Marriage Act for the Registrar to issue a ‘certificate of no impediment to marriage’. It is sworn before a Commissioner for oaths, Magistrate, Consular Officer etc.

It is presented to the Registrar of Marriages.

Title: > Affidavit of Negation of Spousal Consent
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This affidavit is required by the Transferee (buyer) or Chargee (financier) where the Owner of a property is either divorced, widowed, not married or married but the property does not constitute matrimonial property. REQUIREMENTS: • Description of the property. PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for Oaths/Magistrate/Consular Officer/Notary Public. • Present the affidavit to the buyer or financier.

Title: > Affidavit of Spousal Consent
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This affidavit is required by the Transferee (buyer) or Chargee (financier) where the Owner of a property is married and the property constitutes matrimonial property. REQUIREMENTS: • Description of the property. PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for Oaths/Magistrate/Consular Officer/Notary Public. • Present the affidavit to the buyer or financier.

Title: > Affidavit of Good Conduct
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is used as an alternative to a Certificate of Good Conduct for employment or visa applications etc. NB: You should only fill in this affidavit if you have never been convicted of a Felony (major criminal offence). PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for Oaths/Magistrate/Consular Officer/Notary Public. • Present the affidavit to the requiring authority.

Title: > Affidavit of Financial Support for a Student Visa
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This affidavit is required for Visa applications by students going to study abroad. It is made by the person providing financial support to the student eg parent, sponsor etc. REQUIREMENTS: • Students name and passport no. • Name of University/College. • Country where the University/college is located. • Supporting documents i.e certified Bank statements, a copy of scholarship letter, receipt for paid tuition fees; receipt for paid accommodation PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for Oaths/Magistrate/Consular Officer/Notary Public. • Present the affidavit to the requiring Embassy.

Title: > Affidavit of Consent to Child Travel by both Parents
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This Affidavit is sworn by both parents. It is required by Immigration Officer when a child is travelling unaccompanied. REQUIREMENTS: • Name and age of minor • Name, ID and telephone of the person to receive the child at the port of destination. PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. The child to carry 2 originals during travel and to present to immigration officer if required.

Title: > Affidavit of Consent to Child Travel by a Single Parent
Content:
ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT

This Affidavit is sworn by a single parent. It is required by Immigration Officer when a child is travelling unaccompanied.

REQUIREMENTS: • Name and age of minor • Proof of single parenthood. • Name, ID and telephone of the person to receive the child at the port of destination.

PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • The child to carry 2 originals during travel and to present to immigration officer if required.

Title: > Affidavit for Change of Phone Number on NTSA TIMS (Individual)
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is made in support of application for ‘Change of telephone number on NTSA TIMS’ by an Individual. REQUIREMENTS • Old telephone number. • New Phone number. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Present affidavit together with your Original ID and Copy to an NTSA office or Huduma Centre.

Title: > Affidavit & Letter for Deregistration of Tax PIN
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit and letter are required by KRA to deregister a Tax PIN upon dissolution of a Company. REQUIREMENTS • Name and Tax PIN of Company • Gazette notice no. for dissolution of the Company PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit and letter. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Submit the affidavit and letter for cancellation of tax pin and tax obligations on Itax portal (Registration > e-cancellation)

Title: > Affidavit & Form CR7 for Change of Directors Particulars
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit and Form CR7 require to be filed with Registrar of Companies to update change of Director’s particulars e.g email, phone number, address etc. REQUIREMENTS • Name and address of Director. • Name of Company and Company number. • Particulars of change eg email, phone number, address etc. • Name and address of the person to lodge this application with the Registrar e.g director, company secretary, agent etc. PROCESS • Fill in this form. • The affidavit is sworn before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Upload the affidavit and form CR7 (Notice for Change of Particulars) on the Business Registration Services portal on e-citizen.

Title: > Affidavit for Surrender of Shares
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This Affidavit is required to be filed with the Registrar of Companies upon voluntary surrender of shares by a shareholder. REQUIREMENTS • Name of Company. • Type of shares – whether ordinary or preference. • Number of shares. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Upload the affidavit with application for surrender of shares on the Business Registration Services portal on e-citizen.

Title: > Affidavit for Renewal of Engineers License
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is required by an Engineer when renewing a practicing licence. REQUIREMENTS • Engineer registration number. • Engineering classification (e.g Consulting Engineer; Professional Engineer). PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Submit the affidavit together with application for renewal of practicing certificate to the Engineering Board of Kenya.

Title: > Affidavit for Removal of Wrong Tax Obligations on KRA Pin
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This affidavit is required by KRA to remove wrongly assigned tax obligations on personal Tax PIN e.g VAT and PAYE to Students or Monthly Rental Income (MRI) to Tenants and Agents. REQUIREMENTS: • Tax PIN. • Proof that the tax obligations are wrongly assigned e.g student ID and transcripts confirming you were not employed, letter from chief confirming you do not own a rental property etc. PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Submit the affidavit and application for removal of wrongful tax obligations to the Tax Service Office or email to callcentre@kra.go.ke.

Title: > Affidavit for Proof of Residence
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is required by Employers, on Visa applications, financial institutions etc to confirm the applicants current residence. REQUIREMENTS • Document to prove your permanent residence eg water bill, electricity bill, fixed telephone bill, Tenancy/lease agreement or Title Document. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. Submit the affidavit to the relevant Authority

Title: > Affidavit for Confirmation of Name before Marriage (by a Married Woman)
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This Affidavit is required by a married woman who changed her name after marriage but her Certificates and other documents are in her Maiden name. REQUIREMENTS: • Maiden name PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Present it to the requiring authority eg employers, insurance companies etc.

Title: > Affidavit for Lost or Damaged Share Certificate
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is required by the Company Secretary to issue a replacement Share Certificate. REQUIREMENTS • Name of company. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Make application for replacement of Share Certificate to the Company.

Title: > Affidavit for Lost or Damaged Number Plate
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is required by NTSA on application for replacement of a lost or damaged number plate. REQUIREMENTS • Motor vehicle registration number. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Obtain a police abstract • Take motor vehicle for tape lift • Submit the affidavit together with the police abstract and tape lift on NTSA TIMS

Title: > Affidavit for Lost Exam Certificate
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This affidavit is required by Kenya National Examination Council (KNEC) when applying for replacement of a lost exam Certificate. REQUIREMENTS: • Type of lost certificate and year of examination PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Report the loss or damage to police. Obtain a police abstract. • Apply for a replacement on KNEC portal.

Title: > Affidavit for Lost Exam Certificate (by Representative)
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is required by Kenya National Examination Council (KNEC) when applying for replacement of a lost exam Certificate. REQUIREMENTS • Type of lost certificate and year of examination PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Report the loss or damage to police. Obtain a police abstract. • Apply for a replacement on KNEC portal.

Title: > Affidavit for Lost/Damaged Logbook
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is required by NTSA when replacing a lost or damaged log book. REQUIREMENTS • Motor vehicle registration number. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Obtain a police abstract (if lost) • Take motor vehicle for tape lift • Submit the affidavit together with the Police abstract and Tape Lift report on on application for a duplicate logbook on NTSA TIMS portal.

Title: > Affidavit for Discrepancy in Names
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is required by a person whose names on the National ID are different from names on other certificates and title documents to correct the discrepancy. REQUIREMENTS • Certificates with different names from national ID. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Present it to the requiring authority.

Title: > Affidavit for Confirmation of Marriage
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is used as proof of marriage if one is married under customary law, to Employers, NHIF, Insurance applications and exemption for stamp duty etc. REQUIREMENTS • Name and ID number of Spouse. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for Oaths/Magistrate/Consular Officer/Notary Public. • Present it as proof of your marriage to the requiring authority.

Title: > Affidavit of Change of Phone Number on NTSA TIMS by a Company
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit and resolution are made in support of application for ‘Change of telephone number on NTSA TIMS’ by a Company. REQUIREMENTS • Name of the company. • Old Telephone number. • New Telephone number. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit and resolution. • The affidavit to be signed before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • The resolution should be signed by the Chairperson and another Director or Company Secretary. • Present this affidavit, resolution and certificate of incorporation in support of application for change of telephone number to NTSA office or Huduma Centre near you.

Title: > Affidavit for Change of Name after Marriage
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This Affidavit is required by a married woman to change her name on ID adopting her husband’s name. REQUIREMENTS: • Husbands name. • Husbands ID number. • Date of marriage. PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Attach to the application for change of name by a married woman to change ID.

Title: > Affidavit for Change of Motor Vehicle Engine
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is required by NTSA to register change of motor vehicle engine. REQUIREMENTS • Motor vehicle registration number. • Old engine number. • New engine number. • Chassis number. • Proof of source of engine eg import documents, purchase agreement etc. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Take motor vehicle for tape lift. • Apply for change of Motor vehicle engine on NTSA portal and Upload this affidavit.

Title: > Affidavit for Replacement of a Lost/Damaged Passport by a Minor
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This affidavit is required by the Immigration department when applying for replacement of a lost or damaged passport (for a Minor). REQUIREMENTS: • Name and age of minor • Passport number for the minor. • Proof of guardianship e.g birth certificate or court order. PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Report the loss or damage to police. Obtain a police abstract. • Write a short letter explaining how the loss or damage occurred. • Make application for replacement with Immigration department.

Title: > Affidavit for Replacement of a Lost/Damaged Passport by an Adult
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This affidavit is required by the Immigration department when applying for replacement of a lost or damaged passport (by an Adult). REQUIREMENTS: • Passport number. PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Report the loss or damage to police. Obtain a police abstract. • Write a short letter explaining how the loss or damage occurred. • Make application for replacement with Immigration department.

Title: > Affidavit for Replacement of a Lost/Damaged Passport by a Representative
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT: This affidavit is required by the Immigration department when applying for replacement of a lost or damaged passport. It can be used for an aged or ill person who cannot personally attend to Immigration department REQUIREMENTS: • Name and age of person being represented (Applicant) • Passport number Applicant. • Proof of representation e.g power of attorney, court order or medical certificate. PROCESS: • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Report the loss or damage to police. Obtain a police abstract. • Write a short letter explaining how the loss or damage occurred. • Make application for replacement with Immigration department.

Title: > Affidavit for a Lost or Damaged Certificate of Insurance
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This affidavit is required by Insurance company in support of an application for replacement of a lost or damaged Certificate of Insurance. REQUIREMENTS • Policy number. PROCESS • Fill in this affidavit. • Sign before a Commissioner for oaths, Notary Public, Magistrate or Consular officer. • Make application for replacement of insurance policy the insurance Company.

Title: > Receipt/Acknowledgement of Payment
Content: ABOUT THIS DOCUMENT This receipt is used as proof of payment. REQUIREMENTS • Name and address of the Payee – Person entitled to the payment. • Name of the Payer - person making the payment. • Name of the person receiving the payment (on behalf of the payee). PROCEDURE • Fill in this document. • The person receiving the money to sign. • Each party to keep a copy.

Title: > Acceptance of Resignation by Employer
Content: ABOUT DOCUMENT This letter is given by an Employer after receipt of a resignation letter from an Employee. REQUIREMENTS • Name and address of employee. PROCESS • Fill in and sign this letter. • Serve the letter to the employee.
